A '''foreign minister''' or '''minister of foreign affairs''' (less commonly ''for foreign affairs'') is generally a [[Cabinet (government)|cabinet]] [[Minister (government)|minister]] in charge of a [[sovereign state|state]]'s [[foreign policy]] and [[foreign relations|relations]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreedictionary.com/Minister+of+Foreign+Affairs|title=Minister of Foreign Affairs|publisher=}}</ref>
==Difference in titles== In some nations, such as [[India]], the Foreign Minister is referred to as the [[Ministry of External Affairs (India)|Minister for External Affairs]]; or, as in the case of [[Brazil]], [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Brazil)|Minister of Foreign Affairs]]; or, still others, such as states created from the former [[Soviet Union]], call the position the Minister of External Relations. In the United States, the equivalent to the foreign ministry is called the [[United States Department of State|Department of State]], and the equivalent position is known as the [[United States Secretary of State|Secretary of State]]. Other common titles may include Minister of Foreign Relations. In many Spanish and Portuguese-speaking countries in Latin America, the foreign minister is colloquially called "[[chancellor#Foreign minister|Canciller]]".
Diplomats themselves and historians often refer to the foreign ministry by its local address, for example, the [[Ballhausplatz]] in [[Vienna]] housed the [[Foreign Ministry of Austria-Hungary]]; the [[Quai d'Orsay]] in [[Paris]] for France's [[Ministry of Europe and Foreign Affairs]]; the [[Itamaraty Palace]] in [[Brasília]] is the headquarters of the [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Brazil)|Ministry of External Relations]] in Brazil; the [[Wilhelmstraße]], in [[Berlin]], was the location of the [[Federal Foreign Office|German Foreign Office]]; and [[Foggy Bottom]], a neighborhood of [[Washington, D.C.]], houses the [[United States Department of State|Department of State]]. Indonesians also often refers to their [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs|Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_(Indonesia)#Ministers]] as "Pejambon", since the ministry's main headquarters is located at Pejambon Street, [[Central Jakarta]]. During the [[Russian Empire]], which lasted until 1917, the term used was the [[Pevchesky Bridge|Choristers' Bridge]] in [[Saint Petersburg]]. In contrast, the Italian ministry was called the Consulta.<ref>David Stevenson, "The Diplomats" in Jay Winter, ed. ''The Cambridge History of the First World War: Volume II: The State'' (2014) vol 2 p 68.</ref>
==Powers of position== A foreign minister's powers can vary from government to government. In a classic [[parliamentary system]], a foreign minister can potentially exert significant influence in forming [[foreign policy]] but when the government is dominated by a strong [[prime minister]] the foreign minister may be limited to playing a more marginal or subsidiary role in determining policy. Similarly, the political powers invested in the foreign minister are often more limited in [[presidential system|presidential governments]] with a strong [[executive branch]]. Since the end of [[World War II]], it has been common for both the foreign minister and [[defense minister]] to be part of an inner cabinet (commonly known as a [[National Security Council|national security council]]) in order to coordinate defense and [[diplomatic policy]]. Although the 19th and early 20th centuries saw many heads of government assume the foreign ministry, this practice has since become uncommon in most [[developed nation]]s.
==Responsibilities== Along with their political roles, foreign ministers are also traditionally responsible for many diplomatic duties, such as hosting foreign world leaders and going on [[state visits]] to other countries. The foreign minister is generally the most well-traveled member of any cabinet.
* In the United Kingdom, the minister responsible for foreign policy (as well as the [[British overseas territories]]) is the [[Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs]] (Foreign Secretary). Before 1968, the [[Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs]] only handled relations with foreign (non-[[Commonwealth of Nations|Commonwealth]]) countries, while relations with Commonwealth countries and colonies were handled by the [[Secretary of State for Commonwealth Affairs]]. For the same reason, in Commonwealth countries other than the United Kingdom, the ministers responsible for handling relations with both Commonwealth and non-Commonwealth countries were formerly usually designated ministers for External Affairs. * In the United States, the [[United States Secretary of State|Secretary of State]] handles foreign policy and is the senior [[United States Cabinet|Cabinet]] officer. The name of the post comes from several domestic duties.
Although it is very rare for there to be any sub-national foreign minister post, sometimes there is a minor external relations position. The [[European Union]] has dealt with external relations in certain areas since its inception (see [[European Commissioner for Trade|EU Trade Commissioner]]) and has a [[High Representative]] as its chief diplomat. However her duties are primarily to implement [[EU foreign policy]], rather than formulate it.

The '''General Synod''' is the title of the governing body of some church organizations. ==The Anglican Communion== ===The Church of England===
{{Main|General Synod of the Church of England}}
In the [[Church of England]], the General Synod, which was established in 1970 (replacing the [[Church Assembly (Church of England)|Church Assembly]]), is the legislative body of the Church.
===Episcopal Church of the United States=== In the [[Episcopal Church in the United States of America]], the equivalent is [[General Convention of the Episcopal Church in the United States of America|General Convention]].
===Other member churches=== '''General Synods of other churches within the [[Anglican Communion]]''' *[[Anglican Church of Australia]] *[[General Synod of the Anglican Church of Canada|Anglican Church of Canada]] *[[Church of Ireland]] *[[Anglican Church in Aotearoa, New Zealand and Polynesia]] *[[Scottish Episcopal Church]] *[[General Synod of Hong Kong Sheng Kung Hui|Hong Kong Sheng Kung Hui]] (Anglican Church in Hong Kong)
==Other Churches== The [[United Church of Christ]] in the United States also calls their main governing body a General Synod. It meets every two years and consists of over 600 delegates from various congregations and conferences.
The [[Associate Reformed Presbyterian Church]] has as its highest Church court the General Synod. The ARP General Synod meets yearly (in recent years, it has, almost without exception, been held at [[Bonclarken]]). The delegates to the General Synod of the [[ARP Church]] are the elder representatives elected from each church's Session and all ministers from all presbyteries that comprise the Church (excluding ministers and elders from the independent ARP Synods of [[Mexico]] and [[Pakistan]]).
The [[Evangelical Church of Augsburg and Helvetic Confession in Austria]] and the [[United Evangelical Lutheran Church of Germany]] each call their main legislative bodies Generalsynode. In the [[Evangelical Church in Prussia]] the legislating body was called Generalsynode between 1846 and 1953.
The governing body of the [[Reformed Church in America]], a [[Calvinism|Calvinist]] denomination in the United States and Canada, is known as the General Synod.
"Kirkemøtet", the governing body of the [[Church of Norway]] is normally translated to General Synod. It convenes once a year, and consists of 85 representatives, of whom seven or eight are sent from each of the dioceses.
The [[Batak Christian Protestant Church]] (BPCP), or ''Huria Kristen Batak Protestan'' (abbreviated HKBP), held a twice-a-year General Synod (Sinode Godang), to discuss about matters in HKBP, and to elect the new ''Ephorus'' (or Board) for the HKBP. The first General Synod of HKBP was held in 1922.
==Other uses== In the North American [[Lutheran]] tradition, '''General Synod''' refers to a church body which existed from 1820–1918. See [[Evangelical Lutheran General Synod of the United States of North America]].
==See also== * [[Church of England#Organisation|How the Church of England is organised]] * [[List of Church of England Measures]] * [[General Assembly (presbyterian church)]]
== External links == * [http://www.etoile.co.uk/Speech/Inaug7thSynod2000.html Queen's Speech at inauguration of seventh General Synod] * [http://www.cofe.anglican.org/about/gensynod/ Church of England's General Synod website] * [http://peterowen.org.uk/articles/gsmembers.html List of current members]* [http://www.ucc.org/synod/ United Church of Christ General Synod 25 (2005)] * [http://www.arpsynod.org/government.html Associate Reformed Presbyterian Church Government]

{{Infobox award | name = Gruber Prize for Women's Rights | image = | alt = | description = Advancing the rights of women and girls around the world | presenter = [[Peter and Patricia Gruber Foundation]] | location = | reward = [[US$]]500,000 | year = 2003 | year2 = 2011 | website = {{URL|http://gruber.yale.edu}} }}
The '''Gruber Prize for Women's Rights''', established in 2003, was one of five international prizes worth US$500,000 awarded by The [[Peter and Patricia Gruber Foundation]], an American non-profit organization.
The Peter and Patricia Gruber Foundation Women's Rights Prize was presented to an individual or group that has made significant contributions, often at great personal or professional risk, to furthering the rights of women and girls in any area and to advancing public awareness of the need for [[gender equality]] to achieve a just world. Recipients were selected by a distinguished panel of international [[women's rights]] experts/activists from nominations that are received from around the world.
The Foundation honored and encouraged educational excellence, [[social justice]] and scientific achievements that better the [[human condition]].
In 2011, the Prize for Women's Rights was discontinued.<ref>{{cite web|title=Yale and Patricia and Peter Gruber Announce Establishment of the Gruber Foundation at Yale|url=http://gruber.yale.edu/press/yale-and-patricia-and-peter-gruber-announce-establishment-gruber-foundation-yale|publisher=Yale University|date=May 16, 2011}}</ref>
==Recipients== ;2003 *[[Navanethem Pillay]]: South African judge, previously a judge of the [[International Criminal Court]], and since 2008, the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights. *[[Pro-Femmes Twese Hamwe]]: organization in Rwanda<ref name=tnt20130302>{{cite news|title=Rwanda: First Lady Pays Tribute to Profemme|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201303040092.html?viewall=1|newspaper=[[The New Times (Rwanda)|The New Times]]|date=2 March 2013|author=Frank Kanyesigye}}</ref> ;2004 *[[Sakena Yacoobi]]: founder, Afghan Institute of Learning *the [[Afghan Institute of Learning]] ;2005 *[[Shan Women's Action Network]] *[[Women's League of Burma]] ;2006 *[[Unión Nacional de Mujeres Guatemaltecas]]: women's organization in Guatemala *[[Julie Su (attorney)|Julie Su]] for [[Sweatshop Watch]]: organization in the U.S. state of California *[[Cecilia Medina Quiroga]]: Chilean judge, currently serving on the [[Inter-American Court of Human Rights]] ;2007 *[[Pinar Ilkkaracan]] of Istanbul, Turkey, and two organizations she helped establish: [[Women for Women’s Human Rights – New Ways (WWHR)]] and the Coalition for Sexual and Bodily Rights in Muslim Societies (CSBR) ;2008 *[[Yanar Mohammed]], co-founder of Organization of Women’s Freedom in Iraq, has become the focal point for women’s rights activism in Iraq *[[Sapana Pradhan Malla]], a leader in securing legal reforms protecting the fundamental reproductive and property rights of women in Nepal, is president of the Forum for Women, Law & Development * Dr. Nadera Shalhoub-Kevorkian, a leading feminist scholar, therapist and activist, has worked to end domestic violence against Palestinian women, particularly what have been referred to as honor killings; living in Israel, she has trained women activists in the West Bank and Gaza and established a hotline for reporting abuse ;2009 *[[Leymah Gbowee]], executive director of Women Peace and Security Network Africa, who was instrumental in bringing about the end to civil war in Liberia and getting women's groups represented in negotiations and demilitarization efforts. *Women's Legal Centre (WLC), a non-profit law center based in South Africa that seeks to achieve equality for women, particularly black women. ;2010 *[[The Center for Reproductive Rights]] and [[CLADEM]] (Comité de América Latina y El Caribe para la Defensa de los Derechos de la Mujer), two organizations extending and defending the rights of women through litigation, law reform, and education, helping to advance women's sexual and reproductive rights. ;2011 *[[AVEGA Agahozo]] was founded by survivors of the 1994 [[Rwandan Genocide]]. The organisation seeks to improve the lives of fellow survivors (mostly widows) by improving healthcare access, housing opportunities, education, job-training, and advocacy.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.gruberprizes.org/GruberPrizes/WomensRights.php Peter and Patricia Gruber Foundation Women's Rights Prize]

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} '''[[HTTP]] Strict Transport Security''' ('''HSTS''') is a web security policy mechanism that helps to protect websites against protocol downgrade attacks and [[session hijacking|cookie hijacking]]. It allows web servers to declare that web browsers (or other complying user agents) should interact with it using only secure [[HTTPS]] connections,HTTPS refers to HTTP layered over [[Transport Layer Security]] (TLS/SSL). Such secured HTTP connections are denoted by the [[Uniform resource identifier|URI]] [[URI scheme|scheme name]] of "https", and this protocol stack is often colloquially referred to as the "HTTPS protocol". and never via the insecure HTTP protocol. HSTS is an [[Internet Engineering Task Force|IETF]] [[Internet standard|standards track]] protocol and is specified in RFC 6797. The HSTS Policy is communicated by the server to the user agent via an [[HTTPS]] response [[List of HTTP header fields|header]] field named "Strict-Transport-Security".{{Cite web|url=https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Strict-Transport-Security|title=Strict-Transport-Security|website=[[MDN Web Docs]]|publisher=[[Mozilla]]|language=en-US|access-date=31 January 2018}} HSTS Policy specifies a period of time during which the user agent should only access the server in a secure fashion.{{Cite IETF|title=HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS)|sectionname=HSTS Policy|rfc=6797|last1=Hodges|first1=Jeff|last2=Jackson|first2=Collin|last3=Barth|first3=Adam|date=November 2012|publisher=[[Internet Engineering Task Force|IETF]]|section-url=https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6797#section-5.2|access-date=31 January 2018|doi=10.17487/RFC6797}} As the HSTS HTTP Header is only recognized when sent over an HTTPS connection, websites can still allow users to interact with the website using HTTP, to allow compatibility with non-HTTPS user agents. == Specification history == The HSTS specification was published as RFC 6797 on 19 November 2012 after being approved on 2 October 2012 by the [[IESG]] for publication as a [[Internet Standard#Proposed Standard|Proposed Standard]] [[Request for Comments|RFC]].{{cite web | url = https://www.ietf.org/mail-archive/web/websec/current/msg01401.html | title = [websec] Protocol Action: 'HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS)' to Proposed Standard (draft-ietf-websec-strict-transport-sec-14.txt) | date = 2 Oct 2012 | accessdate = 2 Oct 2012 }} The authors originally submitted it as an [[Internet-Draft]] on 17 June 2010. With the conversion to an Internet-Draft, the specification name was altered from "Strict Transport Security" (STS) to "HTTP Strict Transport Security", because the specification applies only to [[HTTP]].{{cite web | url = //www.ietf.org/mail-archive/web/hasmat/current/msg00025.html | author = Jeff Hodges | title = Re: [HASMAT] "STS" moniker (was: IETF BoF @IETF-78 Maastricht: HASMAT...) | date = 30 June 2010 | accessdate = 22 July 2010 }} The HTTP response header field defined in the HSTS specification however remains named "Strict-Transport-Security". The last so-called "community version" of the then-named "STS" specification was published on 18 December 2009, with revisions based on community feedback.{{cite web | url = //lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-archive/2009Dec/att-0048/draft-hodges-strict-transport-sec-06.plain.html | title = Strict Transport Security -06 | date = 18 December 2009 | accessdate = 23 December 2009 }} The original draft specification by Jeff Hodges from [[PayPal]], Collin Jackson, and Adam Barth was published on 18 September 2009.{{cite web | url = //lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-archive/2009Sep/att-0051/draft-hodges-strict-transport-sec-05.plain.html | title = Strict Transport Security -05 | date = 18 September 2009 | accessdate = 19 November 2009 }} The HSTS specification is based on original work by Jackson and Barth as described in their paper “ForceHTTPS: Protecting High-Security Web Sites from Network Attacks”.{{cite web | url = https://crypto.stanford.edu/forcehttps/ | title = ForceHTTPS: Protecting High-Security Web Site from Network Attacks | date = April 2008 | accessdate = 19 November 2009 }} Additionally, HSTS is the realization of one facet of an overall vision for improving web security, put forward by Jeff Hodges and Andy Steingruebl in their 2010 paper ''The Need for Coherent Web Security Policy Framework(s)''.{{cite web | url = http://www.thesecuritypractice.com/the_security_practice/2010/10/the-need-for-coherent-web-security-policy-frameworks.html | title = The Need for Coherent Web Security Policy Framework(s) | last = Hodges | first = Jeff | author2=Steinguebl, Andy | date = 29 October 2010 | accessdate = 21 November 2012 }} == HSTS mechanism overview == A server implements an HSTS policy by supplying a header over an HTTPS connection (HSTS headers over HTTP are ignored). For example, a server could send a header such that future requests to the domain for the next year (max-age is specified in seconds; 31,536,000 is equal to one non-leap year) use only HTTPS: Strict-Transport-Security: max-age=31536000. When a web application issues HSTS Policy to user agents, conformant user agents behave as follows (RFC 6797):{{cite web | url = https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6797#section-5 | title = Section 5. HSTS Mechanism Overview | work = RFC 6797 | publisher = IETF | last = Hodges | first = Jeff |author2=Jackson, Collin |author3=Barth, Adam | date = November 2012 | accessdate = 21 November 2012 }} # Automatically turn any insecure links referencing the web application into secure links. (For instance, http://example.com/some/page/ will be modified to https://example.com/some/page/ ''before'' accessing the server.) # If the security of the connection cannot be ensured (e.g. the server's [[Transport Layer Security|TLS]] [[Public key certificate|certificate]] is not trusted), the user agent must terminate the connection (RFC 6797 section 8.4, Errors in Secure Transport Establishment) and should not allow the user to access the web application (section 12.1, No User Recourse). The HSTS Policy helps protect web application users against some passive ([[eavesdropping]]) and active network [[Attack (computing)|attacks]].{{cite web | url = https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6797#section-2.3 | title = 2.3. Threat Model | work = RFC 6797 | publisher = IETF | last = Hodges | first = Jeff |author2=Jackson, Collin |author3=Barth, Adam | date = November 2012 | accessdate = 21 November 2012 }} A [[man-in-the-middle attack]]er has a greatly reduced ability to intercept requests and responses between a user and a web application server while the user's browser has HSTS Policy in effect for that web application. == Applicability == The most important security vulnerability that HSTS can fix is SSL-stripping [[man-in-the-middle attack]]s, first publicly introduced by [[Moxie Marlinspike]] in his 2009 BlackHat Federal talk "New Tricks For Defeating SSL In Practice".{{cite journal |url=https://blackhat.com/presentations/bh-dc-09/Marlinspike/BlackHat-DC-09-Marlinspike-Defeating-SSL.pdf |title=New Tricks For Defeating SSL In Practice |work= }}{{YouTube|MFol6IMbZ7Y|Defeating SSL Using Sslstrip}} The SSL (and [[Transport Layer Security|TLS]]) stripping attack works by transparently converting a secure [[HTTPS]] connection into a plain HTTP connection. The user can see that the connection is insecure, but crucially there is no way of knowing whether the connection ''should'' be secure. Many websites do not use TLS/SSL, therefore there is no way of knowing (without prior knowledge) whether the use of plain HTTP is due to an attack, or simply because the website hasn't implemented TLS/SSL. Additionally, no warnings are presented to the user during the downgrade process, making the attack fairly subtle to all but the most vigilant. Marlinspike's sslstrip tool fully automates the attack. HSTS addresses this problem by informing the browser that connections to the site should always use TLS/SSL. The HSTS header can be stripped by the attacker if this is the user's first visit. [[Google Chrome]], [[Firefox|Mozilla Firefox]], [[Internet Explorer]] and [[Microsoft Edge]] attempt to limit this problem by including a "pre-loaded" list of HSTS sites.{{cite web | url = https://www.chromium.org/sts | author = Adam Langley | title = Strict Transport Security | work = The Chromium Projects | date = 8 July 2010 | accessdate = 22 July 2010 }}{{cite web | url = https://blog.mozilla.org/security/2012/11/01/preloading-hsts/ | author = David Keeler | title = Preloading HSTS | date = 1 November 2012 | accessdate = 6 February 2014 | work = Mozilla Security Blog }} Unfortunately this solution cannot scale to include all websites on the internet. See [[HTTP Strict Transport Security#Limitations|limitations]], below. HSTS can also help to prevent having one's [[HTTP cookie#Cookie theft and session hijacking|cookie-based website login credentials stolen]] by widely available tools such as [[Firesheep]].{{cite web | url = http://identitymeme.org/archives/2010/10/29/firesheep-and-hsts-http-strict-transport-security/ | author = Jeff Hodges | title = Firesheep and HSTS (HTTP Strict Transport Security) | date = 31 October 2010 | accessdate = 8 Mar 2011 }} Because HSTS is time limited, it is sensitive to attacks involving shifting the victim's computer time e.g. using false [[Network Time Protocol|NTP]] packets.{{cite web | url=https://www.blackhat.com/docs/eu-14/materials/eu-14-Selvi-Bypassing-HTTP-Strict-Transport-Security.pdf | title=Bypassing HTTP Strict Transport Security | date=2014-10-17 | accessdate=2014-10-22 | author=Jose Selvi}} == Limitations == The initial request remains unprotected from active attacks if it uses an insecure protocol such as plain HTTP or if the [[Uniform Resource Identifier|URI]] for the initial request was obtained over an [[insecure channel]].{{cite web | url = https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6797#section-14.6 | title = Section 14.6. Bootstrap MITM Vulnerability | work = RFC 6797 | publisher = IETF | last = Hodges | first = Jeff |author2=Jackson, Collin |author3=Barth, Adam | date = November 2012 | accessdate = 21 November 2012 }} The same applies to the first request after the activity period specified in the advertised HSTS Policy max-age (sites should set a period of several days or months depending on user activity and behavior). [[Google Chrome]], [[Firefox|Mozilla Firefox]] and [[Internet Explorer]]/[[Microsoft Edge]] address this limitation by implementing a "HSTS preloaded list", which is a list that contains known sites supporting HSTS.{{cite web | url= http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ie/archive/2015/02/16/http-strict-transport-security-comes-to-internet-explorer.aspx | title = HTTP Strict Transport Security comes to Internet Explorer | accessdate=16 February 2015 |author1=Bell, Mike |author2=Walp, David | date=February 16, 2015}} This list is distributed with the browser so that it uses HTTPS for the initial request to the listed sites as well. As previously mentioned, these pre-loaded lists cannot scale to cover the entire Web. A potential solution might be achieved by using [[Domain name system|DNS]] records to declare HSTS Policy, and accessing them securely via [[DNSSEC]], optionally with certificate fingerprints to ensure validity (which requires running a validating resolver to avoid [[last mile]] issues).{{cite web | title=HTTP Strict Transport Security | url=https://simon.butcher.name/archives/2011/09/11/HTTP-Strict-Transport-Security | author=Butcher, Simon | date=11 September 2011 | accessdate=27 March 2012 }} {{Quote box | quote = For example; suppose a site contains a link to ''https://example.com/'', the HSTS could be stripped by rewriting the URLs to ''http://example.org/''; with attacker sitting in the middle, receiving traffic from ''http://example.org/'' and proxying it to ''https://example.com/'' | author = Junade Ali | source = ''Performing & Preventing SSL Stripping: A Plain-English Primer''{{cite web|last1=Ali|first1=Junade|title=Performing & Preventing SSL Stripping: A Plain-English Primer|url=https://blog.cloudflare.com/performing-preventing-ssl-stripping-a-plain-english-primer/|website=Cloudflare Blog|date=20 October 2017}} |width = 50% |align = right }} Junade Ali has noted that HSTS is often ineffective against the use of phony domains; by using DNS-based attacks, it is possible for a Man-in-the-Middle interceptor to serve traffic from an artificial domain which is not on the HSTS Preload list, this is made possible by DNS Spoofing Attacks{{cite web|last1=Maksutov|first1=A. A.|last2=Cherepanov|first2=I. A.|last3=Alekseev|first3=M. S.|title=Detection and prevention of DNS spoofing attacks|url=http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/abstract/document/8071970/|website=2017 Siberian Symposium on Data Science and Engineering (SSDSE)|pages=84–87|doi=10.1109/SSDSE.2017.8071970|date=2017}}. Even with an "HSTS preloaded list", HSTS can't prevent advanced attacks against TLS itself, such as the [[BEAST (computer security)|BEAST]] or [[CRIME (security exploit)|CRIME]] attacks introduced by Juliano Rizzo and Thai Duong. Attacks against TLS itself are [[Orthogonal#Computer science|orthogonal]] to HSTS policy enforcement. See {{IETF RFC|6797}} for a discussion of overall HSTS security considerations. === Privacy issues === HSTS can be used to near-indelibly tag visiting browsers with recoverable identifying data ([[HTTP cookie#Supercookie|supercookies]]) which can persist in and out of browser "[[Privacy mode|incognito]]" privacy modes. By creating a web page that makes multiple HTTP requests to selected domains, for example if twenty browser requests to twenty different domains are used, theoretically over one million visitors can be distinguished (220) due to the resulting requests arriving via HTTP vs. HTTPS; the latter being the previously recorded binary "bits" established earlier via HSTS headers.{{cite web|url=https://nakedsecurity.sophos.com/2015/02/02/anatomy-of-a-browser-dilemma-how-hsts-supercookies-make-you-choose-between-privacy-or-security/|title=The HSTS super cookie forcing you to choose: "privacy or security?" -|work=sophos.com|accessdate=1 December 2015}} == Browser support == [[File:Chromium HSTS settings screenshot.png|alt=Settings page for HTTPS Strict Transport Security within Chromium 45, showing the status of the security policy for the domain "en.wikipedia.org".|border|right|428x428px|Settings page for HTTPS Strict Transport Security within Chromium 45, showing the status of the security policy for the domain "en.wikipedia.org".]] * [[Chromium (web browser)|Chromium]] and [[Google Chrome]] since version 4.0.211.0{{cite web | url = https://dev.chromium.org/sts | author = The Chromium Developers | title = Strict Transport Security - The Chromium Projects | date = 17 November 2010 | accessdate = 17 November 2010 }}{{cite web | url = http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-webapps/2009JulSep/1148.html | author = Jeff Hodges | title = fyi: Strict Transport Security specification | date = 18 September 2009 | accessdate = 19 November 2009 }} * [[Firefox]] since version 4; with Firefox 17, [[Mozilla]] integrates a list of websites supporting HSTS. * [[Opera (web browser)|Opera]] since version 12{{cite web | url = http://www.opera.com/docs/specs/presto2.10/#m210-244 | author = Opera Software ASA | title = Web specifications support in Opera Presto 2.10 | date = 23 April 2012 | accessdate = 8 May 2012 }} * [[Safari (web browser)|Safari]] as of [[OS X Mavericks]]{{cite web | url=https://twitter.com/agl__/status/414112266938617856 | author = @agl__ ([[Adam Langley]]) | title = Confirmed. See ~/Library/Cookies/HSTS.plist. Includes Chromium preloads as of some date and processes HSTS headers. | work = on Twitter | accessdate = 20 December 2013 }} * [[Internet Explorer 11]] on [[Windows 8.1]] and [[Windows 7]] when [https://support.microsoft.com/kb/3058515 KB 3058515] is installed (Released on Windows Update in June 2015){{cite web|url=http://blogs.windows.com/msedgedev/2015/06/09/http-strict-transport-security-comes-to-internet-explorer-11-on-windows-8-1-and-windows-7/|title=HTTP Strict Transport Security comes to Internet Explorer 11 on Windows 8.1 and Windows 7|work=windows.com|accessdate=12 June 2015}} * [[Microsoft Edge]] and [[Internet Explorer 11]] on [[Windows 10]]{{cite web | url=https://status.modern.ie/httpstricttransportsecurityhsts | title=Internet Explorer Web Platform Status and Roadmap | accessdate=14 April 2014}}{{cite web | url=https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/ie/2015/01/22/project-spartan-and-the-windows-10-january-preview-build/ | title=Project Spartan and the Windows 10 January Preview Build - IEBlog | accessdate=23 January 2015}} * [[BlackBerry 10]] Browser and [https://developer.blackberry.com/native/reference/cascades/bb__cascades__webview.html WebView] since BlackBerry OS 10.3.3. == Deployment best practices == Depending on the actual deployment there are certain threats (e.g. cookie injection attacks) that can be avoided by following best practices. * HSTS hosts should declare HSTS policy at their top-level domain name. For example, an HSTS host at https://sub.example.com should also answer with the HSTS header at https://example.com. The header should specify the includeSubDomains directive.{{cite web|url=https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-websec-strict-transport-sec-14#page-16|title=HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) 6.1.2.|work=ietf.org|author=Hodges, et al.|accessdate=11 November 2016}} * In addition to HSTS deployment, a host for https://www.example.com should include a request to a resource from https://example.com to make sure that HSTS for the parent domain is set and protects the user from potential cookie injection attacks performed by a MITM that would inject a reference to the parent domain (or even http://nonexistentpeer.example.com), which the attacker then would answer.{{Citation needed|date=March 2018}} == See also == {{Portal|Internet}} * [[Content Security Policy]] * [[HTTP Public Key Pinning]] * [[HTTPsec]] == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == * [https://garron.net/crypto/hsts/hsts-2013.pdf The State of HSTS Deployment: A Survey and Common Pitfalls] provides an analysis of HSTS deployment statistics, patterns, mistakes, and best practices. * {{IETF RFC|6797}} – HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) * [https://tools.ietf.org/wg/websec/charters IETF WebSec Working Group] * [https://www.twit.tv/shows/security-now/episodes/262 Security Now 262: Strict Transport Security] * [https://www.owasp.org/index.php/HTTP_Strict_Transport_Security_Cheat_Sheet Open Web Application Security Project (OWASP): HSTS description] * [https://projects.dm.id.lv/Public-Key-Pins_test Online browser HSTS and Public Key Pinning test] * [https://www.htbridge.com/websec/ Online HSTS Test for Web Servers] * [https://hstspreload.org/ HSTS Preload Submission] for Google Chrome, Mozilla Firefox, Safari, IE 11, and Edge * [https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Strict-Transport-Security Strict-Transport-Security] on [[MDN Web Docs]] {{SSL/TLS}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Http Strict Transport Security}} [[Category:Computer security]] [[Category:Computer security standards]] [[Category:Cryptography]] [[Category:Hypertext Transfer Protocol headers|Strict Transport Security]] {{DISPLAYTITLE:iCivics}} '''iCivics, inc.''' (formerly Our Courts) is a [[501(c)(3)]] [[non-profit organization]] in the United States that provides [[Educational game|educational online games]] and lesson plans to promote [[civics]] education and encourage students to become active citizens.<ref name=":0" /> iCivics was founded in 2008 by retired [[Supreme Court of the United States]] Justice [[Sandra Day O'Connor]]. iCivics’s stated mission is to “ensure every student receives a high-quality civic education, and becomes engaged in – and beyond – the classroom.”<ref name=":1" />
iCivics, inc. is supported by private donations and grants and had annual expenses of $2.2 million in 2015.<ref name=":0" /> Among the top contributors were the [[Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation|Gates Foundation]] and the [[John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation|MacArthur Foundation]].<ref name=":0">iCivics, Inc. (2016). ''iCivics Annual Report 2015''. Retrieved from https://www.icivics.org/sites/default/files/annual_report_2015.pdf</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.macfound.org/grantees/392/|title=iCivics — MacArthur Foundation|website=www.macfound.org|access-date=2016-07-22}}</ref> In the same year, iCivics served more than 85,000 educators and 3 million students, including half of all middle school [[social studies]] classrooms in America.<ref name=":0" />
==History== Justice O’Connor developed the Our Courts project in partnership with [[Georgetown University Law School]] and [[Arizona State University]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.icivics.org/news/icivics-celebrates-gaming-milestone|title=iCivics Celebrates Gaming Milestone|last=Curley|first=Jeffrey|publisher=iCivics|accessdate=19 July 2011}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://cabengo.com/projects/our-courts/|title=Cabengo » Our Courts|website=cabengo.com|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> In March 2009, Justice O'Connor went on [[The Daily Show]] with [[Jon Stewart]] to promote Our Courts and civics education.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.comedycentral.com/videos/index.jhtml?videoId=220242&title=sandra-day-o-connor-pt--1|title=Justice O'Connor Interview|last=The Daily Show|publisher=The Daily Show|accessdate=18 July 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/law/2009/03/04/justice-oconnor-not-only-smart-and-moderate-but-funny/|title=Justice O'Connor: Not Only Smart and Moderate...But Funny!|last=Jones|first=Ashby|date=4 March 2009|publisher=Wall Street Journal|accessdate=18 July 2011}}</ref> Our Courts added ''Supreme Decision'' and ''Do I Have A Right?'' to the website in August 2009.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.edweek.org/login.html?source=http://www.edweek.org/ew/articles/2009/08/20/01civics.h29.html&destination=http://www.edweek.org/ew/articles/2009/08/20/01civics.h29.html&levelId=2100|title=Celebrities Lend Weight to Promote Civics Education|date=August 20, 2009 (updated August 25, 2009)|work=[[Education Week]]|publisher=Education Week|author=Zehr, Mary Ann|accessdate=19 July 2011}}</ref> It was incorporated as iCivics, inc. in May 2010 as the variety of content and users began to expand more rapidly.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://www.icivics.org/news/introducing-our-new-site|title=Introducing our new site {{!}} iCivics|website=www.icivics.org|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> A more comprehensive website was launched, supplementing the gaming modules with classroom lessons on the branches of government.
[[Above the Law (blog)|Above The Law]] sponsored a ''Do I Have A Right?'' challenge in 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://abovethelaw.com/2010/01/the-atl-do-i-have-a-right-challengecongratulations-from-justice-oconnor/|title=The ATL ‘Do I Have A Right?’ Challenge: Congratulations from Justice O’Connor|last=Lat|first=David|publisher=Above The Law|accessdate=19 July 2011}}</ref> Justice O'Connor was the keynote speaker at [[Games for Change]] in 2010, and iCivics was featured at the Games for Change conference in New York in 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/charles-tsai/al-gore-games-social-good_b_881017.html|title=Al Gore: 'Games Are the New Normal'|last=Tsai|first=Charles|publisher=Huffington Post|accessdate=18 July 2011}}</ref> The [[Washington Post]] Editorial Board highlighted the shortcomings of traditional civics education, and the efforts of iCivics.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/making-history-and-civics-a-priority/2011/06/17/AGb1tYZH_story.html|title=Making History and Civics a Priority|last=Editorial Board|date=17 June 2011|publisher=Washington Post|accessdate=19 July 2011}}</ref>
In 2011 the website added seven games and 16 lesson plans, and had over 700,000 unique visitors.<ref>iCivics, Inc. (2012). ''Annual Report 2011''. Retrieved from www.guidestar.org/ViewEdoc.aspx?eDocId=2772999&approved=True</ref> By 2013 it was the most widely adopted civics curriculum in America.<ref name=":3" />
Currently, the governing board of iCivics includes O’Connor as well as current Justice Sonia Sotomayor and the Honorable Robert Henry, president of Oklahoma City University. The executive director of iCivics is Louise Dubé, previously Managing Director of Digital Learning at [[WGBH-TV|WGBH]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.icivics.org/our-team|title=Our Team {{!}} iCivics|website=www.icivics.org|access-date=2016-07-25}}</ref>
==Mission== Justice O’Connor initially envisioned Our Courts as a response to a perceived misunderstanding of the justice system in America.<ref name=":2" /> As keynote speaker at the [[National Council for the Social Studies|NCSS]] annual conference in 2007, she noted “that while two-thirds of Americans know at least two judges on FOX Television’s ‘American Idol’ reality program, less than one in 10 can name the Chief Justice of the United States.” <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.americanbar.org/newsletter/publications/law_matters_home/oconnor.html|title=Law Matters Winter 2008 {{!}} Justice O'Connor Addresses NCSS Conference|website=www.americanbar.org|access-date=2016-07-25}}</ref> At present, ourcourts.org maintains this mission,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ourcourts.org/our-approach/|title=Our Approach - Our Courts America|website=ourcourts.org|access-date=2016-07-25}}</ref> but iCivics has a broader mission incorporating education on the legislative and executive branches of government as well as civics at a local level.<ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.guidestar.org/profile/38-3796793|title=iCivics - GuideStar Profile|last=|first=|date=|website=www.guidestar.org|publisher=|access-date=2016-07-25|quote=Self-reported}}</ref>
The organization focuses on broadly improving civics education but also on closing the civics [[Achievement gap in the United States|education gap]].<ref name=":0" /> O'Connor saw the state of civics education as a result of the failure of traditional education methods, as well as funding cuts and lower graduation requirements imposed by the [[No Child Left Behind Act]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nea.org/home/38146.htm|title=Courting Kids|access-date=2016-07-26}}</ref> Our Courts collaborator [[James Paul Gee|James Gee]], a professor of literacy at Arizona State University, convinced her that educational games were the key to civics education, due to their capacity to teach problem solving.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/28/technology/sandra-day-oconnor-supreme-court-video-games.html|title=A Supreme Court Pioneer, Now Making Her Mark on Video Games|last=Singer|first=Natasha|date=2016-03-27|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=2016-07-26}}</ref>
iCivics games have been evaluated for their educational effectiveness in a handful of research studies. ''Branches of Power'' was shown to be both engaging and educational for a majority of students in a test group.<ref>Lewis, Carrie, Jason Lancaster, Wilhelmina Savenye, and Nancy Haas. "A Formative Evaluation of the Balance of Power Game and Curriculum." ''The Journal of Applied Instructional Design'' 3, no. 3 (December 2013): 5-16.</ref> A significant number of students also play the games again at home, greatly increasing absorption of concepts and improving test scores.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://trevorowens.org/portfolio/owens_Effects%20of%20learning%20from%20a%20civics%20video%20game.doc|title=Effects of learning from a civics video game|last=Owens|first=Trevor|date=December 2010|website=Trevor Owens|publisher=|access-date=2016-07-25}}</ref> The general iCivics curriculum has been shown to be an effective mechanism for education on civics topics as measured by scores on the US citizenship test. It was particularly effective among younger students in grades 4-6 and less effective among high school seniors.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=LeCompte|first=Karen|last2=Moore|first2=Brandon|last3=Blevins|first3=Brooke|date=Fall 2011|title=The Impact of iCivics on Students’ Core Civic Knowledge|url=|journal=Research in the Schools|volume=18|issue=2|doi=|pmid=|via=}}</ref> The interactive writing exercise Drafting Board also improved [[persuasive writing]] skills among 8th graders.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://civicyouth.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/WP_76_KawashimaGinsberg.pdf|title=Summary of Findings from the Evaluation of iCivics’ Drafting Board Intervention|last=Kawashima-Ginsberg|first=Kei|date=December 2012|website=CIRCLE|publisher=THE CENTER FOR INFORMATION & RESEARCH ON CIVIC LEARNING & ENGAGEMENT|access-date=}}</ref>
The organization is currently working on extending its curriculum to high school and reaching more high school educators. It currently serves one in four high school government and history teachers.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.guidestar.org/profile/38-3796793|title=iCivics - GuideStar Profile|website=www.guidestar.org|access-date=2016-07-25}}</ref>
==Content== iCivics hosts lesson plans, games, online workshops and other materials for teachers and students of American civics. All online materials are free to registered users.
=== Games === iCivics currently hosts nineteen different educational games, developed in partnership with [[Filament Games]] (with the exception of Supreme Decision, produced with Studio Mobile, Cabengo and the Center for Children & Technology).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.icivics.org/credits|title=Credits {{!}} iCivics|website=www.icivics.org|access-date=2016-07-22}}</ref> Curriculum and design of each game is provided by employees of iCivics, and dart, programming, and sound design is provided by Filament. * Activate - Build an advocacy campaign from the local to the national level. * Argument Wars - Argue one of several landmark Supreme Court cases. * Branches of Power - Control the three different branches of federal government. * Cast Your Vote - Interview candidates for office in a debate setting and try to vote for the one you most agree with. * Counties Work - Control a municipal government, balancing taxes with public services and helping the community grow. * Court Quest - help citizens resolve cases by guiding them through the different parts of the court system. * Crisis of Nations - As Commander-in-Chief, take military and diplomatic action to promote the national interest. * Do I Have A Right? - field a team of specialist lawyers in Constitutional litigation cases. * Do I Have A Right?: Bill of Rights Edition - field a team of lawyers with specialties in each of the [[United States Bill of Rights|first ten amendments.]] * Executive Command - As President of the United States, take responsibility for giving the [[State of the Union]] speech, signing legislation, running the departments of the executive branch, negotiating with other branches of government and other nations, and deciding on military aid, war and diplomacy efforts. * Immigration Nation - decide who is allowed to immigrate to the US by determining their citizenship, work visa or refugee status. * Lawcraft - Bring a bill through Congress, compromising with other legislators and adding amendments until it passes and becomes law. * People's Pie - Control the budget for the federal government by selecting tax revenue, borrowing level, and spending programs which the public will approve. * Power Play - Argue the respective advantages of state power and federal power. * Represent Me! - As a legislator, strategically support bills which will help your constituents most. * Responsibility Launcher - remind people of their civic duties and privileges as citizens of the United States. * Supreme Decision - help decide a court case on student dress policy, similar to [[Tinker v. Des Moines Independent Community School District|Tinker v. Des Moines]]. * We The Jury - as a jurist, hear a case, weigh the arguments and evidence, and persuade fellow jurists to come to a specific conclusion on the case. * Win the White House - manage a presidential campaign by strategically raising funds, polling voters, launching media campaigns, and making personal appearances. Attempt to win the majority of electoral votes.
=== Lesson plans === Lesson plans on iCivics are also provided for free, with content and curriculum guidance provided by iCivics staff. These plans emphasize student engagement by including activities such as crosswords and short quizzes as well as reference to their online games. Units of study include the history and development of the Constitution, the branches and levels of government, the rights and duties of citizens, politics and policy, and international affairs. Beyond education on government, there is also a unit on persuasive writing.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.icivics.org/products/lesson-plans|title=Lesson Plans {{!}} iCivics|website=www.icivics.org|access-date=2016-07-22}}</ref> A set of lessons developed with the [[Boys & Girls Clubs of America]] was designed to be used during their meetings instead of a traditional school period.<ref>Boys and Girls Clubs of America. (2013). ''2012 annual report.'' Retrieved from<nowiki/>http://www.bgca.org/whoweare/Documents/2012_Annual_ReportLOW.pdf</ref>

page.title: Initiatives and referendums in the United States

revision.comment: Undid revision 870579087 by [[Special:Contributions/2600:1700:1EA0:5390:5C59:64C2:3AC0:43A|2600:1700:1EA0:5390:5C59:64C2:3AC0:43A]] ([[User talk:2600:1700:1EA0:5390:5C59:64C2:3AC0:43A|talk]]) rv unsourced edit
revision.text:
In the [[politics of the United States]], the process of '''initiatives and referendums''' allow citizens of many [[U.S. state]]s<ref>{{cite web |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160211180917/http://www.iandrinstitute.org/statewide_i%26r.htm |url=http://www.iandrinstitute.org/statewide_i%26r.htm |title=State by state listing of where they are used |publisher=Iandrinstitute.org |date= |accessdate=2010-06-17 |archive-date=2016-02-11 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> to place new [[legislation]] on a popular ballot, or to place legislation that has recently been passed by a [[legislature]] on a ballot for a popular [[direct democracy|vote]]. Initiatives and referendums, along with [[recall election]]s and popular [[primary election]]s, are signature reforms of the [[Progressive Era]]; they are written into several [[State constitution (United States)|state constitutions]], particularly in the [[Western United States|West]].
== History == {{Main|History of direct democracy in the United States}}
The Progressive Era was a period marked by reforms aimed at breaking the concentrated power, or [[monopoly]], of certain [[corporation]]s and [[Trust company|trusts]]. Many Progressives believed that [[State legislature (United States)|state legislature]]s were part of this problem and that they were essentially "in the pocket" of certain wealthy interests. They sought a method to counter this—a way in which average persons could become directly involved in the political process. One of the methods they came up with was the initiative and referendum. Between 1904 and 2007, some 2231 statewide referendums initiated by citizens were held in the USA. 909 of these initiatives have been approved. Perhaps even greater is the number of such referendums that have been called by state legislatures or mandatory—600 compared to 311 civic initiatives in 2000-2007.
== Types of initiatives and referendums == [[File:Initiatives, referendums, and legislative referral in the United States.svg|thumb|right|500px|'''States that allow direct initiated constitutional amendments'''{{legend|Navy|States that allow legislatively-referred and direct initiative statutes, or legislatively-referred and direct initiated constitutional amendments or referendums.|Border=1px #AAAAAA solid}} {{legend|MediumBlue|States that allow legislatively-referred and indirect initiative statutes, or legislatively-referred and direct initiated constitutional amendments or referendums.|Border=1px #AAAAAA solid}} {{legend|RoyalBlue|Illinois allows legislatively-referred initiative statutes, or legislatively-referred and direct initiated constitutional amendments or referendums.|Border=1px #AAAAAA solid}} {{legend|DarkTurquoise|Mississippi allows legislatively-referred, indirect, and direct initiated constitutional amendments.|Border=1px #AAAAAA solid}} {{legend|Aqua|Florida allows legislatively-referred, and direct initiated constitutional amendments.|Border=1px #AAAAAA solid}} '''States and federal district that allow initiated statutes''' {{legend|Gold|Massachusetts allows legislatively-referred and indirect initiative statutes, or legislatively-referred and indirect initiated constitutional amendments or referendums, with the specific '''initiative petition''' term used for all directly-voted initiatives.|Border=1px #AAAAAA solid}} {{legend|Yellow|States that allow legislatively-referred, indirect, and direct initiative statutes, or legislatively-referred initiated constitutional amendments or referendums.|Border=1px #AAAAAA solid}} {{legend|Orange|Idaho allows direct initiative statutes, or legislatively-referred initiated constitutional amendments or referendums.|Border=1px #AAAAAA solid}} {{legend|DarkOrange|States that allow indirect initiative statutes, or legislatively-referred initiated constitutional amendments or referendums.|Border=1px #AAAAAA solid}} {{legend|OrangeRed|Washington D.C. allows direct initiative statutes.|Border=1px #AAAAAA solid}} '''States that allow referendums''' {{legend|Lime|States that allow legislatively-referred state statutes, or legislatively-referred initiated constitutional amendments or referendums. Or citizen initiated referendums of existing statutes.|Border=1px #AAAAAA solid}} {{legend|LightGray|Delaware allows legislatively-referred state statutes or citizen initiated referendums of existing statutes.|Border=1px #AAAAAA solid}} '''States that allow legislative referral only''' {{legend|Pink|Kentucky allows legislatively-referred state statutes and legislatively-referred initiated constitutional amendments.|Border=1px #AAAAAA solid}} {{legend|Red|States that allow legislatively-referred initiated constitutional amendments only.|Border=1px #AAAAAA solid}}]]
Initiatives and referendums—collectively known as "ballot measures," "propositions," or simply "questions"—differ from most legislation passed by representative democracies; ordinarily, an elected [[legislature|legislative body]] develops and passes laws. Initiatives and referendums, by contrast, allow citizens to vote directly on legislation.
In many [[U.S. states]], ballot measures may originate by several different processes:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iandrinstitute.org/Quick%20Fact%20-%20What%20is%20I&R.htm |title=What is I&R? |publisher=Iandrinstitute.org |date= |accessdate=2010-06-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100725175114/http://www.iandrinstitute.org/Quick%20Fact%20-%20What%20is%20I%26R.htm |archivedate=2010-07-25 |df= }}</ref> Overall, 27 US states and Washington D.C. allow some form of [[direct democracy]].
=== Initiatives === An [[Initiative]] is a means through which any citizen or organization may gather a predetermined number of signatures to qualify a measure to be placed on a ballot, and to be voted upon in a future election. (These may be further divided into [[constitutional amendment]]s and statutory initiatives. Statutory initiatives typically require fewer signatures to qualify to be placed on a future ballot.)
==== Initiated state statute ==== The following US states allow initiated state statutes, also called initiative (direct) state statutes:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ballotpedia.org/wiki/index.php/Initiated_state_statute|title=Initiated state statute - Ballotpedia|publisher=}}</ref> *Alaska *Arizona *Arkansas *California *Colorado *Idaho *Maine *Massachusetts *Michigan *Missouri *Montana *Nebraska *Nevada *North Dakota *Ohio *Oklahoma *Oregon *South Dakota *Utah *Washington *Wyoming
==== Indirect initiative state statute ==== The following US states allow indirect state statutes:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ballotpedia.org/wiki/index.php/Indirect_initiative_statute|title=Indirect initiative statute - Ballotpedia|publisher=}}</ref> * Maine * Massachusetts (proper term is ''initiative petition'', for all forms of referendum voting) * Michigan * Nevada * Ohio * Utah * Washington * Wyoming
While the following US states allow legislative action to void a petition: * Alaska
==== Indirect initiated state constitutional amendment ==== The initiative process, for proposing constitutional amendments, may be "direct" or "indirect". States that permit indirect constitutional amendments, like [[Mississippi]], permit legislators to propose an alternative amendment which is placed on the ballot alongside the direct citizen proposal.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.sos.ms.gov/links/elections/home/tab2/InitiativeGuide.pdf | title = Constitutional Initiative in Mississippi: A Citizen's Guide | page = 2 | date = 2009-01-14 | accessdate = 2010-04-29 | publisher = Secretary of State, Mississippi}}</ref>
The following US states allow indirect initiated state constitutional amendments: * Massachusetts * Mississippi
==== Initiated state constitutional amendment ==== An initiated constitutional amendment is an amendment to a state's [[constitution]] that results from petitioning by a state's citizens. By utilizing this [[initiative]] process, citizens can propose and vote on constitutional amendments directly, without need of [[legislative referral]]. When a sufficient number of citizens have signed a petition requesting it, a proposed constitutional amendment is then put to the vote.
In the United States, while no court or legislature needs to approve a proposal or the resultant initiated constitutional amendment, such amendments may be overturned if they are challenged and a court confirms that they are unconstitutional.<ref name="Mason2003">{{cite book|last=Mason|first=Colin|authorlink=Colin Mason|title=The 2030 Spike: Countdown to Global Catastrophe|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NjCGbmrf7MUC&pg=PA212|accessdate=29 April 2010|date=October 2003|publisher=Earthscan|isbn=978-1-84407-018-3|page=212}}</ref> Most states that permit the process require a 2/3 majority vote.<ref name="Mason2003"/>
Not all amendments proposed will receive sufficient support to be placed on the ballot. Of the 26 proposed petitions filed in the state of [[Florida]] in its 1994 general election, only three garnered sufficient support to be put to the vote.<ref>Jameson, P.K. and Marsha Hosack. (1996) "[http://www.law.fsu.edu/journals/lawreview/downloads/232/jameson.pdf Citizen Initiative in Florida: An Analysis of Florida's Constitutional Initiative Process, Issues, and Statutory Initiative Alternatives] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120302180529/http://www.law.fsu.edu/journals/lawreview/downloads/232/jameson.pdf |date=2012-03-02 }}." pp. 1-2. Originally published in ''Florida State University Law Review'' 23:417.</ref>
The following US states allow initiated (direct) state constitutional amendments: {{columns-list|colwidth=22em|style=width: 400px;| * Arizona * Arkansas * California * Colorado * Florida * Illinois * Massachusetts * Michigan * Mississippi * Missouri * Montana * Nebraska * Nevada * North Dakota * Ohio * Oklahoma * Oregon * South Dakota }}
=== Referendum === Popular [[Referendum]], in which a predetermined number of signatures (typically lower than the number required for an initiative) qualifies a ballot measure for repealing a specific act of the legislature.
The following US states allow referendum: {{columns-list|colwidth=22em|style=width: 400px;| * Alaska * Arizona * Arkansas * California * Colorado * Delaware * Idaho * Illinois * Indiana <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.in.gov/dlgf/8789.htm|title=DLGF: Referendum Information|author=|date=|website=www.in.gov|accessdate=3 April 2018}}</ref> * Kentucky * Maine * Maryland * Massachusetts * Michigan * Missouri * Montana * Nebraska * Nevada * New Mexico * North Dakota * Ohio * Oklahoma * Oregon * South Dakota * Utah * Washington }}
=== Legislative referral === [[Legislative referral]] (aka "legislative referendum"), in which the legislature puts proposed legislation up for popular vote (either voluntarily or, in the case of a constitutional amendment, as a necessary part of the procedure.)
==== Legislatively-referred state statute ==== The following US states allow legislatively-referred state statutes:<ref>[http://ballotpedia.org/wiki/index.php/Legislatively-referred_state_statute Legislatively-referred state statute] </ref> {{columns-list|colwidth=22em|style=width: 400px;| * Arizona * Arkansas * California * Colorado * Delaware * Illinois * Kentucky * Maine * Maryland * Massachusetts * Michigan * Missouri * Montana * Nebraska * Nevada * New Mexico * North Dakota * Ohio * Oklahoma * Oregon * Pennsylvania * South Dakota * Utah * Washington }}
==== Legislatively-referred state constitutional amendment ==== With the exception of Delaware, 49 US states allow legislatively-referred state constitutional amendments.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ballotpedia.org/wiki/index.php/Legislatively-referred_constitutional_amendment|title=Legislatively referred constitutional amendment - Ballotpedia|publisher=}}</ref>
== Objections to the system == The initiative and referendums process have critics. Some argue that initiatives and referendums undermine [[representative government]] by circumventing the elected representatives of the people and allowing the people to directly make [[policy]]: they fear excessive [[majoritarianism]] ([[tyranny of the majority]]) as a result, believing that [[minority group]]s may be harmed.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Gamble | first1 = Barbara S. | year = 1997 | title = Putting Civil Rights to a Popular Vote | url = | journal = American Journal of Political Science | volume = 41 | issue = 1| pages = 245–269 |jstor=2111715 | doi = 10.2307/2111715 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Hajnal | first1 = Zoltan | last2 = Gerber | first2 = Elisabeth R. | last3 = Louch | first3 = Hugh | year = 2002 | title = Minorities and Direct Legislation: Evidence from California Ballot Proposition Elections | url = | journal = Journal of Politics | volume = 64 | issue = | pages = 154–177 |doi=10.1111/1468-2508.00122}}</ref><ref>Gray, Virginia & Russell L. Hanson. ''Politics in the American States''. 9 ed. Washington, DC: CQ Press, 2008. p. 141.</ref>
Other criticisms are that competing initiatives with conflicting provisions can create legal difficulties when both pass;<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB122385788118627429?mod=googlenews_wsj |title=Was the Price Too High for Colorado Initiative Deal? - WSJ.com |publisher=Online.wsj.com |date=2008-10-13 |accessdate=2010-06-17}}</ref> and that when the initiatives are proposed before the end of the legislative session, the legislature can make statutory changes that weaken the case for passing the initiative.<ref>[http://www.coloradoan.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20081009/NEWS01/810090332 ]{{dead link|date=June 2010}}</ref> Yet another criticism is that as the number of required signatures has risen in tandem with populations, "initiatives have moved away from empowering the average citizen" and toward becoming a tool for well-heeled special interests to advance their agendas.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thevotersofaz.com/?cat=4 |title=Vote NO on Prop 105 » In The News |publisher=Thevotersofaz.com |date= |accessdate=2010-06-17}}</ref> John Diaz wrote in an editorial for the ''San Francisco Chronicle'' in 2008:<ref>{{cite web|author=John Diaz |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2008/10/11/INAB139LLK.DTL |title=A long way from the grassroots |publisher=Sfgate.com |date=2008-10-12 |accessdate=2010-06-17}}</ref>
{{quote|There is no big secret to the formula for manipulating California's initiative process. Find a billionaire benefactor with the ideological motivation or crass self-interest to spend the $1-million plus to get something on the ballot with mercenary signature gatherers. Stretch as far as required to link it to the issue of the ages (this is ''for the children'', Prop. 3) or the cause of the day (this is about ''energy independence and renewable resources'', Props. 7 and 10). If it's a tough sell on the facts, give it a sympathetic face and name such as "[[California Proposition 9 (2008)|Marsy's Law]]" (Prop. 9, victims' rights and parole) or "[[California Proposition 4 (2008)|Sarah's Law]]" (Prop. 4, parental notification on abortion). Prepare to spend a bundle on soft-focus television advertising and hope voters don't notice the fine print or the independent analyses of good-government groups or newspaper editorial boards ... Today, the initiative process is no longer the antidote to special interests and the moneyed class; it is their vehicle of choice to attempt to get their way without having to endure the scrutiny and compromise of the legislative process.}}
In some cases, voters have passed initiatives that were subsequently repealed or drastically changed by the legislature. For instance, legislation passed by the voters as an Arizonan [[medical cannabis]] initiative was subsequently gutted by the [[Arizona legislature]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Golden |first=Tim |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C0CEED7123FF934A25757C0A961958260 |title=Medical Use of Marijuana To Stay Illegal in Arizona - NYTimes.com |publisher=New York Times |date=1997-04-17 |accessdate=2010-06-17}}</ref> To prevent such occurrences, initiatives are sometimes used to amend the state constitution and thus prevent the legislature from changing it without sending a referendum to the voters; however, this produces the problems of inflexibility mentioned above. Accordingly, some states are seeking a middle route. For example, Colorado's Referendum O would require a two-thirds vote for the legislature to change statutes passed by the voters through initiatives, until five years after such passage. This would allow the legislature to easily make uncontroversial changes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chieftain.com/articles/2008/10/13/news/local/doc48f2d15ad1c1a930126514.txt |title=The Pueblo Chieftain Online :: Referendum O limits constitutional changes |publisher=Chieftain.com |date= |accessdate=2010-06-17}}</ref>
An objection not so much to the initiative concept, but to its present implementations, is that signature challenges are becoming a political tool, with state officials and opposing groups litigating the process, rather than simply taking the issue fight to voters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mansfieldnewsjournal.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20081018/UPDATES01/81018012|title= mansfieldnewsjournal.com|accessdate=October 20, 2008 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> Signatures can be declared void based on technical omissions, and initiatives can be thrown out based on statistical samplings of signatures. Supporters lacking necessary funds to sustain legal battles can find their initiative taken off the ballot.
[[Image:MedicaidForIdahoVan.jpg|thumb|120px|Medicaid for Idaho]] Legislatures themselves may tighten already arduous requirements. E.g., while California or Oregon typically have dozens of [[ballot measure]]s each year, Idaho has had 28 since the 1930s, of which twelve passed. The [[Idaho Legislature]] in 2013 however increased the geographical requirements for putting an initiative on the ballot<ref name="Idaho governor signs bill tightening initiative rules">{{Cite web |url=http://www.spokesman.com/stories/2013/apr/03/idaho-governor-signs-bill-tightening-initiative/ |title=http://www.spokesman.com/stories/2013/apr/03/idaho-governor-signs-bill-tightening-initiative/ |last=Russell |first=Betsy |date=2013-04-03 |website=The Spokesman-Review |access-date=2018-05-29}}</ref> after a trio of unpopular education laws ("Students Come First") were repealed by the voters. Despite the new requirement of the signatures of 6% of the registered voters in 18 of Idaho's 35 legislative districts before May,<ref name="6% of registered voters in 18 of Idaho's 35 legislative districts before May,">{{Cite web |url=https://www.idahopress.com/news/local/medicaid-expansion-petition-away-from-target-still-need-to-wrap/article_493cef58-b6a4-5d98-9404-d39f9d607d79.html |title=Medicaid expansion petition 6,000 away from target, still need to wrap up 11 districts |last=PFANNENSTIEL |first=KYLE |date=2018-04-14 |website=Idaho-Press Tribune |access-date=2018-04-15}}</ref> as of mid-April 2018 the drive to put the [[Medicaid gap]] before the voters on the November ballot (by way of their amending the state constitution, yea or nay)<ref name="Grassroots Initiative Drive">{{Cite web |url=http://www.spokesman.com/blogs/boise/2018/apr/19/medicaid-expansion-initiative-final-push-just-5000-signatures-goal/ |title=Medicaid expansion initiative in final push, just 5,000 signatures from goal |last=Russell |first=Betsy |date=2018-04-19 |website=The Spokesman-Review |access-date=2018-04-19}}</ref> was well on its way to gathering the prerequisite number of signatures in the prerequisite number of legislative districts, much to the surprise of pundits.<ref name="Medicaid for Idaho">{{Cite web |url=http://www.idahostatesman.com/opinion/bill-manny/article208784784.html |title=Luke Mayville and his Medicaid for Idaho campaign are proving us political 'experts' wrong |last=Manny |first=Bill |date=2018-04-13 |website=Idaho Statesman |access-date=2018-04-14}}</ref> Ultimately the organizers had by the April 30 deadline delivered 60,000 signatures to county clerks' offices, which if verified are far more than the 56,192 required.<ref name="60,000 signatures for Medicaid Expansion in Idaho">{{Cite web |url=http://www.idahostatesman.com/opinion/bill-manny/article208784784.html |title=60,000 signatures & counting: How did the upstart Medicaid expansion campaign do it? |last=Manny |first=Bill |date=2018-05-01 |website=The Idaho Statesman |access-date=2018-05-01}}</ref>
==Proposed reforms== Some proposed reforms include paying signature gatherers by the hour, rather than by the signature (to reduce incentives for fraud) and increasing transparency by requiring major financial backers of initiatives to be disclosed to potential signatories. Other proposals include having a "cooling-off" period after an initiative qualifies, in which the legislature can make the initiative unnecessary by passing legislation acceptable to the initiative's sponsors.<ref>http://www.ppic.org/content/pubs/op/OP_1100FSOP.pdf</ref> It has also been proposed that [[Proxy voting#Elections|proxy voting]] be combined with initiative and referendum to form a hybrid of [[direct democracy]] and [[representative democracy]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://larson2008.com/wiki/index.php5?title=Proxy_voting |title=Proxy voting|accessdate=October 21, 2008 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
=== National initiative === The [[national initiative]] is a proposal to amend the [[United States Constitution]] to allow [[ballot initiative]]s at the [[Federal government of the United States|federal level]].
=== Citizens' Initiative Review === Healthy Democracy, and a similar organization in Washington State, proposed a Citizens' Initiative Review process. This brings together a representative cross-section of voters as a [[citizens' jury]] to question and hear from advocates and experts regarding a ballot measure; then deliberate and reflect together to come up with statements that support and/or oppose the measure. The state would organize such a review of each ballot measure, and include the panelists' statements in the voters' pamphlet. Since 2009, Healthy Democracy has led efforts to develop and refine the Citizens' Initiative Review process for use by Oregon voters .
In 2011, the Oregon Legislature approved House Bill 2634, legislation making the Citizens' Initiative Review a permanent part of Oregon elections.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oregon.gov/circ/Pages/index.aspx|title=State of Oregon: Citizens' Initiative Review Commission|website=www.oregon.gov}}</ref> This marked the first time a legislature has made voter deliberation a formalized part of the election process. The CIR is a benchmark in the initiative reform and public engagement fields.
Each state has individual requirements to qualify initiatives for the ballot. Generally, all 24 states and the [[Initiatives and referendums in the District of Columbia|District of Columbia]] follow steps similar to: # File a proposed petition with a designated state official # State review of the proposal and, in several states, a review of the language of the proposal # Prepare ballot title and summary # Petition circulation to obtain the required number of signatures # Petition submitted to state election officials to verify the signatures and qualify the ballot entry
